questions.text: A patient who has taken lithium for some months discontinues it and says ‘the ocean needs a sail as rat needs a tail, so write your exam and don’t fail, results will be out in a mail’. Which of the following symptoms is he exhibiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clang associations
Sail-tail-fail-mail (rhyming is observed which is characteristic of clang associations)
Not flight of ideas, because no specific one word connection
Not tangentiality, because no evidence of losing the track
Not Neologisms, because no new words used

questions.text: A patient was observed in her room alone talking loudly and gesticulating, this is probably an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hallucination

Hallucination refers to perception without sensory input. The patient is having a conversation and gesticulating to someone who is not in the room. Delusion (choice A) refers to false belief (not perception) that is not amenable to reason. In obsessive-compulsive behaviour (choice C), the patient recognizes the irrationality of the compulsion, but not engaging in it causes extreme anxiety. In panic states, the patient experiences extreme anxiety, usually immobilizing or forcing him/her to escape from the situation.

questions.text: Most Common hallucination is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Auditory

Overall the most common hallucinations seen are auditory hallucinations.

questions.text: A young man gets sudden and irresistible urge to carry out an act. Which of the following is an impulse control disorder? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sudden irresistible urge to carry out an act is impulse

Intermittent explosive disorder is an impulse control disorder

questions.text: A middle aged man suddenly becomes detached, and starts writing poems and stories, although it couldn’t be understood by anyone because of language and context was also not rational. This is a disorder of ______?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Form of thought
The clinical sign described is “Neologism” which is form of thought disorder.

questions.text: 22 years old Babu had fight with his neighbour's son. Next day, which going to the bus stop, he felt that 2 uniformed policemen were following him. On reaching home he was frightened and he felt that the neighbours were using radio waves to control his mind. What is his symptom :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Passivity phenomenon


“Using radio waves to control” suggests passivity phenomenon. Although delusion of persecution is also present.

questions.text: Blunting of affect is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Schizophrenia

No expressions

questions.text: The symptom of inability to enjoy previously pleasurable activities is known as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anhedonia

•Loss of interest and pleasure in activities, that were previously pleasurable, is known as anhedonia.

questions.text: A person who is found to be crying suddenly without any stimulus when he was previously laughing and joyous is said to have
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Labile affect

Rapidly fluctuating expressions

questions.text: When the person becomes “disoriented”, the first one to be lost is??
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Time > Place > Person

questions.text: Which of the following feature present in "psychosis" best differentiates it from "neurosis"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Loss of reality contact 

All of 3 options help differentiate psychosis from neurosis but the concept of loss of reality contact is given most priority.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with complains of irritability, hearing voices, suspiciousness since 4 days following an episode of fever. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brief Psychotic Disorder

  • BRIEF PSYCHOTIC DISORDER:
  • Symptoms similar to Schizophrenia
  • Onset- Acute
  • Often preceded by a stressor
  • Often resolves completely
  • Duration- <1 month
  • Rx- Antipsychotics

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is schizophrenic first rank symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Made affect

Schizophrenic first rank symptoms are: (Ref : Niraj Ahuja)
1. Audible thoughts: Voices speaking out thoughts aloud or ‘ thought echo’.
2. Voices heard arguing: Two or more hallucinatory voices discussing the subject in third person.
3. Voices commenting on one’s action.
4. Thought withdrawal: Thoughts cease and subject experiences them as removed by an external force.
5. Thought insertion: Experience of thoughts imposed by some external force on person’s passive mind.
6. Thought diffusion or broadcasting: Experience of thoughts escaping the confines of self and as being experienced by others around.
7. ‘ Made’ feelings or affect.
8. ‘Made’ impulses.
9. ‘Made’ volition or acts: In ‘made’ affect, impulses and volitions, the person experiences feelings, impulses or acts which are imposed by some external force. In ‘made’ volition, for example, one’s own acts are experienced as being under the control of some external force.
10. Somatic passivity: Bodily sensations, especially sensory symptoms, are experienced as imposed on body by some external force.
11. Delusional perception: Normal perception has a private and illogical meaning.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient has been brought to OPD by his family members with history of loosening of clothes at inappropriate places. There are several times when he laughs inappropriately during the interview. His speech is confusing and unpredictably shifts from one topic to another. There is also history of mirror gazing and giggling to self. What is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hebephrenic Schizophrenia
Mirror gazing, giggling, inappropriate laughter, and disorganised behaviour points towards diagnosis of hebephrenia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with better prognosis in schizophrenia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Negative symptoms

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented with complaint that aliens are communicating with him they are sending an electromagnetic radiation to his brain and aliens are asking him to kill his distant relatives. His relative said he has this disease from last 20 years, The patient does not work on farm and stopped going in social functions, patient is aware of time, place and person. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Schizophrenia

“that aliens are communicating with him they are sending an electromagnetic radiation to his brain and aliens are asking him to kill his distant relatives” (Auditory hallucinations commanding the patient : first rank symptom)
Duration more than 6 months (20 years chronic continuous)
Social impairment

questions.text: All are features of catatonia except : (AIIMS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Akathisia (Akathisia is neuroleptic induced disturbance manifesting as inner restlessness)
Catatonia is defined as the presence of three or more of the following  
1. Catalepsy (i.e., passive induction of a posture held against gravity) 
2. Waxy flexibility (i.e., slight and even resistance to positioning by examiner) 
3. Stupor (no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment) 
4. Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
 5. Mutism (i.e., no, or very little, verbal response [Note: not applicable if there is an established aphasia]) 
6. Negativism (i.e., opposing or not responding to instructions or external stimuli)
 7. Posturing (i.e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity) 
8. Mannerisms (i.e., odd caricature of normal actions) 
9. Stereotypies (i.e., repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal directed movements) 
10. Grimacing 
11. Echolalia (i.e., mimicking another's speech) 
12. Echopraxia (i.e., mimicking another's movements)
Others: Ambivalency and ambitendancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a negative symptom in Schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Automatism (Ref: Kaplan Synopsis of Psychiatry 11th edn)

Alogia, Affective flattening and Anhedonia are negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Automatism is seen in seizures

questions.text: Which of the following personality subtype is more prone to develop “folia-a-deux”? (DNB)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dependent 

Dependent and weak members of family are more likely to share the delusions of strong members of family.

questions.text: Which of the following antipsychotic has anti-suicidal role?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clozapine

Lithium and Clozapine have anti-suicidal properties. (CLOZAPINE: VIP DRUG)

questions.text: What is the most common indication of Electro-convulsive therapy in psychiatry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Depression with suicidal tendancies

Most common indication of ECT in depression is in suicidal tendencies

questions.text: What is most common symptom of depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Generalised psychomotor retardation

It is the most common symptom of depression

questions.text: Minimum duration of symptoms required to diagnose major depressive disorder as per DSM-5?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2 weeks

Minimum duration of symptoms needed to diagnose depression is 2 weeks

questions.text: A 42 year old male with a past history of a manic episode presents with an illness of 1 month duration characterized by depressed mood, anhedonia and profound psychomotor retardation. The most appropriate management strategy is prescribing a combination of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antidepressants and mood stabilizers
(This is a case of bipolar depression where you need to give both antidepressant and as well as mood stabilizer. If you give alone antidepressant, than he may go to manic phase)

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came to the OPD with complains of sadness of mood, anhedonia, disturbed sleep and appetite since 3 years. She reports that she is not able to remember the time when she was happy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neurotic depression or Dysthymia
 
Dysthymia:

  • It is the presence of depressive symptoms that are less severe than that of major depressive disorder.
  • But it persists for more than 2 years.
  • Previously k/a neurotic depression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was recently seen by her primary care physician due to complaints of depressed mood, lack of pleasure, sleep problems, decreased appetite and weight, decreased energy, and problems with concentration. She states that these symptoms started when she was fired from her job about 4 weeks ago, and that since then, she has been unable to function. What is the most indicated treatment at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Paroxetine

She has a diagnosis of major depression and the first line treatment is the use of an SSRI medication because of a better side-effect profile compared to the other therapies. Bupropion, would be useful but not the first choice. Alprazolam is simply a benzodiazepine and acts as an anxiolytic, not an antidepressant. Electroconvulsive therapy might be useful if initial therapy did not work or the depression was far more severe and was associated with psychotic features.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are included in the diagnosis of bipolar disorder except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Depression alone

Alone mania is bipolar, but alone depression is not a bipolar

questions.text: What is safer and effective therapeutic concentrations of Lithium to be maintained for acute manic phase in bipolar disorders?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A young man was brought to the outpatient clinic by his family members with history of increased talk, increased alcohol consumption, sexual promiscuity, irritability, decreased sleep, and not feeling tired even after prolonged activity. These changes have been noticed over a period of 2 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mania 

Increased talking, increased alcohol, sexual promiscuity, irritability, decreased sleep, suggestive of mania.

questions.text: A mother who has delivered a baby 1 week back comes with history of tearfulness, irritability and excessive anxiety for no apparent reason. She is suffering from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PP blues

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was referred to a psychiatrist by his physician because he is "too shy." He has problems going to parties, feels anxious about getting close to others, and stays at home in fear that others would laugh at him. When confronted by others, he develops severe anxiety as well as hyperventilation and increased sweating. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Social Anxiety


Social anxiety is characterized by fear of embarrassment in social situations. These patients have problems going out in fear that others will laugh at them.

questions.text: A lady while driving a car meets with an accident. She was admitted in an ICU for 6 months. After being discharged she often gets up in night and feels terrified. She is afraid to sit in a car again. The diagnosis is –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Post traumatic Stress Disorder

After accident.... gets up at night... feels terrified... afraid to sit in a car again... points towards diagnosis of  PTSD. Its an important topic, where we need to read diagnostic criteria ICD and DSM.

questions.text: If a person with OCD, forcibly tries to resist his obsession, what is he likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anxiety


When a person forcibly tries to resist an obsession, it leads to anxiety.

questions.text: In a non-diabetic non-hypertensive patient having some extra beats in pulse. Doctor informed it is benign. But patient is still going for investigations from doctor to doctor and worried about having a major disease. This is a type of: (FMGE 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypochondriacal disorder

Worried about having a major disease is known as hypochondriasis

questions.text: Match the following anxiety disorders with their characteristic features:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

Explanation:

A) Panic Disorder - 3. Sudden episodes of intense fear with physical symptoms: Panic Disorder is characterized by sudden and unexpected episodes of intense fear, often accompanied by physical symptoms such as palpitations, sweating, trembling, and a sense of impending doom.

B) Generalized Anxiety Disorder - 1. Excessive worry about multiple life events: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) involves persistent and excessive worry about various aspects of life, such as work, health, and social interactions, lasting for at least 6 months.

C) Social Anxiety Disorder - 4. Fear of social situations due to concerns about embarrassment: Social Anxiety Disorder, also known as Social Phobia, is characterized by a significant fear of social situations where the individual may be judged, embarrassed, or humiliated.

D) Specific Phobia - 2. Intense fear of a particular object or situation: Specific Phobia involves an intense, irrational fear of a specific object or situation, such as heights, animals, or flying, which leads to avoidance behavior.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A : 4 , B : 1 , C : 2 , D : 3

Correct match is

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman tells the physician that she must drive the route she takes home from work each day at least three times to be sure that she did not hit an animal in the road. Of the following, the most appropriate long-term pharmacological management for this patient is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

An Antidepressant agent


The most effective pharmacological treatment for this patient who has obsessive–compulsive disorder is an antidepressant, particularly a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. Antipsychotics, antianxiety agents, and lithium are less appropriate than an antidepressant for this patient.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy was brought to the child psychiatrist for misbehaving frequently at home and in school with the teacher, often bullies the younger kids and has been caught stealing money on multiple occasions. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE 2020)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Misbehaviour
  • Stealing money
  • Violation of rights of others

Points towards diagnosis of conduct disorder.

questions.text: A girl with a history of loss of consciousness episodes only in front of family members and only in day time. Patient can recall the events at the time of episode, when she regains conscious after 5-10 min, no tongue bite, no history of fecal or urinary incontinence. EEG and MRI brain were normal. Select the true statement regarding her treatment:- (NEET PG 2024 AFTERNOON)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clinical history is suggestive of conversion/pseudoseizure, where the first line of treatment is behavioural therapy.

questions.text: An 18y old first year MBBS girl student, has been experiencing short last episodes of tightness sensation in chest, anxiety and feeling of impending doom. One episode per week for last 3-4 months. The student repeatedly came 3 times to OPD with same symptoms. On investigations, all findings were with in normal limits and she was then referred to psychiatrist. Likely diagnosis (NEET)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Feeling of impending doom, in episodic pattern, with normal investigations, is suggestive of PANIC disorder

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with a diagnosis of delirium has symptoms of psychosis which include: frightening auditory and visual hallucinations and paranoid delusions. Which of the following medications should be chosen first for this man’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Haloperidol.


Haloperidol is a commonly used drug to treat the psychotic symptoms that may be apparent in delirious patients. 
If the patient is agitated, the drug can be safely given IM, but should be switched over to a low dose of oral medication as soon as the patient is willing and/or able to do so. 

Drugs with significant anticholinergic activity should be avoided in delirious patients, as should benzodiazepines in the elderly

questions.text: The drugs rivastigmine and donepezil are used in the treatment of which of the following disorder
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dementia

These are acetylcholinesterase inhibitors, used in treatment of dementias.

questions.text: The following is NOT a feature of dementia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dementia has clear sensorium (no disorientation).

questions.text: Dementia secondary to which of the following is not reversible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stroke

Reversible causes constitute only 15% of initial diagnoses of dementia. It is more commonly seen in younger patients.

questions.text: Korsakoff’s syndrome is characterised by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Impaired procedural memory
 

  • Korsakoff’s syndrome:
  • Cause: Thiamine deficiency
  • Clinical features:

- Personality changes including lack of initiative, diminished spontaneity, and lack of interest or concern (Apathy)
Confabulation
- Executive function deficits
- Passivity

  • Treatment: Thiamine administration

questions.text: Delusion of MORBID JEALOUSY is commonly seen with which of the following SUBSTANCE used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alcohol

  • Jealous type: delusions that the individual's sexual partner is unfaithful (Othello syndrome)
  • It is commonly seen in use of alcohol

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents at the local clinic complaining of abdominal cramps, sweating, runny nose, vomiting, and muscle aches. Examination shows that his pulse is rapid and pupils are dilated. He states that he "feels just awful" and that he has had these symptoms for about 24 hours. The most likely pharmacologic treatment would be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clonidine

The man is suffering from opiate withdrawal. The drug on the list to treat the withdrawal is clonidine.

choices.text: To give I.V. dextrose followed by Injection Thiamine
To give Injection Thiamine and then I.V. dextrose

questions.text: A 28year old male presents to emergency department with symptoms of decreased sleep, palpitations, fearfulness. On examination patient has tremors, BP- 140/90, pulse- 98/min. Patient’s attendee says that he takes alcohol since 10 years and last drink was one day before. All are true about management of this case except -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

To give I.V. dextrose followed  by Injection Thiamine

This is a case of alcohol withdrawal, give thiamine first and dextrose later, to prevent wernicke's encephalopathy.

questions.text: Amotivational syndrome has been described with the use of which of the following substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Cannabis
 

  • Amotivational syndrome:
  • It is a cannabis related syndrome.
  • It is associated with long term heavy use of cannabis.
  • It is characterised by a person’s unwillingness to persist in a task.
  • Loss of ambition and impaired school/ occupational performance.

questions.text: A 65 year old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents to his primary care clinic. Now he is admitted with features of vision loss, confusion and unsteady gait. He cannot recall about the recent events. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

History is suggestive of alcohol related “Wernicke’s Korsakoff syndrome” that is due to deficiency of thiamine

questions.text: A 4 year and eleven month old boy is all the time so restless that the rest of the class is unable to concentrate. He is hardly ever in his seat but roams around the hall. He has difficulty playing quietly. The most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hyperactivity and difficulty concentration point towards diagnosis of ADHD.

questions.text: A two years old girl child is brought to the outpatient with features of hand wringing stereotype movements, impaired language and communication development, breath holding spells, poor social skills and deceleration of head growth after six months of age. The most likely diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Regression of milestones (deceleration of head growth) after normal development till 6 months is highly suggestive of Rett’s syndrome

questions.text: A 8 year old child presents to the OPD with symptoms of persisting pattern of angry & irritable mood and argumentative behavior. He also has other features too such as resistance to directions, and unwillingness to compromise, give in, or negotiate with adults or peers. He is vindictive for his friends and often has no regrets. This is most probably a case of ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ODD
 
The essential features of ODD are a frequent and persisting pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness that is clearly more frequent, more intense, and more persistent across the child’s development than is typically observed in individuals of similar age and developmental level. Argumentative and defiant behaviors are expressed by persistent stubbornness, resistance to directions, and unwillingness to compromise, give in, or negotiate with adults or peers.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to a pediatrician with a year-long history of uncontrollable blinking, which has worsened over the past several weeks. The blinking is worse at some times than at others, and the boy is teased at school because of it. The child also clears his throat repeatedly, although nothing physically wrong can be found. He is doing well at school although he sometimes has trouble completing his homework. The patient has a paternal history of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The first line of treatment for this condition is :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diagnosis is Tourette’s syndrome. The first-line of treatment should be an alpha-adrenergic medication such as clonidine or guanfacine. If ineffective the atypical antipsychotics would be the next class of medications to try.

questions.text: A 2.5 year-old child is brought to a pediatrician for his yearly physical examination. His history reveals various behavioral issues, including poor interaction with peers and family, delayed language development, repetitive movements, and difficulty accepting change. The child stiffens physically when touched, does not respond to the examiner, and does not make eye contact. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A young man is often the object of his friends’ jokes because he drops to the floor whenever he is having a good laugh. Which of the following is this man most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Narcolepsy

  • Loss of tone on emotional events is cataplexy, which is seen in narcolepsy. Remember,
  • Catalepsy: catatonia; cataplexy: narcolepsy

questions.text: Which is the most common symptom of Narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Day time sleep attacks is most common symptom

questions.text: Most common personality disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Anankastic personality disorder is most common personality disorder overall

questions.text: The non-REM (NREM) sleep is commonly associated with
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Night terrors are seen in NREM, nightmares are seen in REM sleep

questions.text: Squeeze technique is used for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Squeeze technique is used for premature ejaculation

questions.text: What is the term used to describe increased sexual desire in males? (NEET)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • Increased sexual desire in males is known as satyriasis
  • Increased sexual desire in females is known as nymphomaniac

questions.text: A young female patient comes with repeated binge eating followed by purging with laxatives. Which of the following is likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bulimia nervosa

Binge eating followed by purging, is suggestive of bulimia

questions.text: Indoor management of anorexia nervosa is done on priority in patients with: (FMGE 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Weight loss >75%
 

CRITERIA FOR ADMISSION TO HOSPITAL in anorexia nervosa:

  • Extremely low body weight: less than 85% of ideal body weight or a BMI < 17.5.
  • Acute medical instability.
  • Rapid, excessive weight loss (~10% weight loss within 3 months).
  • Psychosis or significant risk of suicide.
  • Other serious psychiatric co-morbidities.
  • Failure of outpatient treatment.
  • Involuntary admission is considered when compulsory refeeding is needed to medically stabilize patient and/or decision making capacity is impaired.

questions.text: A female of 23 years of age has come to emergency after suicidal cut of wrist, history of break up with boyfriend, similar history in past of such attempts. There is no history of depression. She behaves very rudely with nurse but when she was attended by handsome male resident doctor, she talked sweetly. Most Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Borderline personality disorder

Persons with borderline personality disorder almost always appear to be in a state of crisis. Mood swings are common. Patients can be argumentative at one moment, depressed the next, and later complain of having no feelings. Patients can have short-lived psychotic episodes (so-called micropsychotic episodes) rather than full-blown psychotic breaks, and the psychotic symptoms of these patients are almost always circumscribed, fleeting, or doubtful. The behavior of patients with borderline personality disorder is highly unpredictable, and their achievements are rarely at the level of their abilities. The painful nature of their lives is reflected in repetitive self-destructive acts. Such patients may slash their wrists and perform other self-mutilations to elicit help from others, to express anger, or to numb themselves to overwhelming affect.

choices.text: Cluster C: Obsessive compulsive personality disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly matched:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A female patient wants to get rid of her tobacco addiction, which drug should be used? (FMGE 2022)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Varenicline and bupropion are both used for smoking/tobacco deaddiction, but varenicline is more effective.

questions.text: Oedipus complex is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Boys of 3-5 years of age

  • Boys of 3-5 years of age : Oedipus complex and castration anxiety
  • Girls of 3-5 years of age : Electra complex and penis envy

questions.text: Which of the following is the psychological defense mechanism in which an individual blames others for his mistake?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rationalisation

Making excuses and giving explanations for one’s own shortcomings or mistakes, is known as rationalisation.

questions.text: A middle aged person with symptoms of anxiety and loneliness was diagnosed with depression. He is to be prescribed with a medication, which is a serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor. Identify the drug. (FMGE 2021)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Venlafaxine is SNRI

questions.text: Disulfiram is a type of: (FMGE 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aversion therapy

questions.text: Most common extrapyramidal side effect? (*)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Akathisia 

  • Akathisia > Pseduoparkinsonism
  • Akathisia is a peculiar state of somatic restlessness manifesting both subjectively and objectively in about 25%-50% patients on antipsychotics. (Ref : IPS, Maudsley guidelines)

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressant agents is most likely to cause extreme sedation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Trazodone
Solution:

  • Trazodone:
  • It is a weak inhibitor of serotonin reuptake and strong antagonist at 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C receptors.
  • The adverse effects of trazadone are partially mediated by α1-adrenergic receptor antagonism.
  • The major side effects are:

Sedation-Therefore used in patients who have depression with insomnia

Priapism

Postural hypotension

choices.text: Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium toxicity
Lithium is avoided in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects

questions.text: A 27 year old female having bipolar disorder was on lithium. Which of the following statement is incorrect? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • In lithium toxicity, hemodialysis is used
  • Lithium is known to cause hypothyroidism
  • Thiazide decrease lithium clearance and hence increase serum lithium levels and increase its toxicity
  • Lithium has known teratogenicity : Ebstein’s anomaly

questions.text: A 35 year old man was taking medication for depression, but had sexual dysfunction. Which drug will you switch him on to address this problem? (FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bupropion

  • Bupropion is NDRI drug that increases sexual desire
  • It causes least amount of sexual dysfunction amongst all antidepressants just like mirtazapine

questions.text: Patient has had manic and depressive episodes and needs treatment. Which of the following causes least weight gain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ziprasidone

Ziprasidone causes least weight gain amongst all atypical antipsychotics
